definition: Prospect Garden/Grand View Garden, a garden in Dream of the Red Chamber
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
surname Guan
to look at/to watch/to observe/to behold/to advise/concept/point of view/outlook
Taoist monastery/palace gate watchtower/platform
surname Yuan
land used for growing plants/site used for public recreation/abbr. for a place ending in 園|园, such as a botanical garden 植物園|植物园, kindergarten 幼兒園|幼儿园 etc
Granny Liu visits the Grand View gardens/(of a simple person) to be overwhelmed by new experiences and luxurious surroundings
pinyin: Liu2 lao3 lao5 jin4 Da4 guan1 yuan2

sentences.english: This park is laid out in imitation of Grand View Garden in "a Dream of Red Mansions".
sentences.chinese: 这个公园是仿照《红楼梦》里的大观园设计的。

sentences.english: Los Angeles, where I live, is a great city for wrinkle watching.
sentences.chinese: 我所在的城市，洛杉机，是皱纹的大观园。

sentences.english: Jinshang Highway, Qingpu, near Grand View Garden.
sentences.chinese: 金商公路708号，青浦区，近大观园。

sentences.english: So, I dreamed myself was standing in the Ta Kuan Garden this morning.
sentences.chinese: 于是乎，今早就很自然的梦到了自己站在大观园里。

sentences.english: That the Beijing Grand View Garden, is too small.
sentences.chinese: 北京的那个大观园，太小了。

sentences.english: Qingwen is one of the most typical characters in A Dream of Red Mansion.
sentences.chinese: 晴雯是《红楼梦》大观园中最有个性的典型人物之一。

definition: A Dream of Red Mansions (first completed edition 1791) by Cao Xueqin 曹雪芹[Cao2 Xue3 qin2], one of the four great novels
Jia Baoyu, male character in The Dream of Red Mansions, in love with his cousin Lin Daiyu 林黛玉 but obliged to marry Xue Baochai 薛寶釵|薛宝钗
Xue Baochai, female character in Dream of Red Mansions, married to Jia Baoyu 賈寶玉|贾宝玉
Granny Liu visits the Grand View gardens/(of a simple person) to be overwhelmed by new experiences and luxurious surroundings
pinyin: Liu2 lao3 lao5 jin4 Da4 guan1 yuan2

definition: Lin Daiyu, female character in The Dream of Red Mansions, cousin and thwarted lover of Jia Baoyu 賈寶玉|贾宝玉
Cao Xueqin (c. 1715-c. 1764), accepted author of A Dream of Red Mansions 紅樓夢|红楼梦[Hong2 lou2 Meng4]
precious jade/treasures
lady's chamber
The Peony Pavilion (1598), play by Tang Xianzu 湯顯祖|汤显祖[Tang1 Xian3 zu3]
red-light district
the Forbidden City/the Imperial Palace in Beijing/same as 故宮|故宫[Gu4 gong1]
Shen Fu (1763-c. 1810), Qing dynasty writer, author of Six Records of a Floating Life 浮生六記|浮生六记[Fu2 Sheng1 Liu4 Ji4]
pavilions and kiosks (in Chinese gardens)
Garden of Many Flowers (name)/Baihua garden in Hongmiao village 洪廟村|洪庙村[Hong2 miao4 cun1], Shandong
Li Ruzhen (c. 1763-c. 1830), Qing novelist and phonologist, author of fantasy novel Jinghua Yuan 鏡花緣|镜花缘 or Flowers in the Mirror
to enjoy the sights (of)
